      Maspoch, D.; Ruiz-Molina, D.; Wurst, K.; Domingo, N.; Cavallini, M.; Biscarini, F.; Tejada, J.; Rovira, C.; Veciana, J. Nat. Mater. 2003, 2, 190– 195
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      39
      A nanoporous molecular magnet with reversible solvent-induced mechanical and magnetic properties
      Maspoch, Daniel; Ruiz-Molina, Daniel; Wurst, Klaus; Domingo, Neus; Cavallini, Massimilliano; Biscarini, Fabio; Tejada, Javier; Rovira, Concepcio; Veciana, Jaume
      Nature Materials (2003), 2 (3), 190-195CODEN: NMAACR; ISSN:1476-1122. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Interest in metal-org. open-framework structures has increased enormously in the past few years because of the potential benefits of using crystal engineering techniques to yield nanoporous materials with predictable structures and interesting properties. Here the authors report a new efficient methodol. for the prepn. of metal-org. open-framework magnetic structures based on the use of a persistent org. free radical (PTMTC), functionalized with three carboxylic groups. Using this approach, the authors create an open-framework structure Cu3(PTMTC)2(py)6(CH3CH2OH)2(H2O), which the authors call MOROF-1, combining very large pores (2.8-3.1 nm) with bulk magnetic ordering. MOROF-1 shows a reversible and highly selective solvent-induced 'shrinking-breathing' process involving large vol. changes (25-35%) that strongly influence the magnetic properties of the material. This magnetic sponge-like behavior could be the 1st stage of a new route towards magnetic solvent sensors.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXhsFGhtLk%253D&md5=c93fc0e7fde10b6275a5ff6aca53bf8e
    40. 40
      Wang, Z. M.; Zhang, B.; Kurmoo, M.; Green, M. A.; Fujiwara, H.; Otsuka, T.; Kobayashi, H. Inorg. Chem. 2005, 44, 1230– 1237
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      40
      Synthesis and Characterization of a Porous Magnetic Diamond Framework, Co3(HCOO)6, and Its N2 Sorption Characteristic
      Wang, Zheming; Zhang, Bin; Kurmoo, Mohamedally; Green, Mark A.; Fujiwara, Hideki; Otsuka, Takeo; Kobayashi, Hayao
      Inorganic Chemistry (2005), 44 (5), 1230-1237CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      [Co3(HCOO)6](CH3OH)(H2O) (1), the isostructural analog of the porous magnet of coordination framework [Mn3(HCOO)6](CH3OH)(H2O), and its desolvated form [Co3(HCOO)6] (2) were prepd. and characterized by x-ray and neutron diffraction methods, IR, thermal analyses, and BET, and their magnetic properties were measured. The parent compd. 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system, space group P21/c, a 11.254(2), b 9.832(1), c 18.108(3) Å, β 127.222(2)°, Z = 4, R1 = 0.0329 at 180 K. It possesses a unit cell vol. that is 9% smaller than [Mn3(HCOO)6](CH3OH)(H2O) due to the smaller radius of Co2+ ion. Compared with the parent compd. 1, the desolvated compd. 2 has slightly larger lattice with cell parameters of a 11.2858(4), b 9.8690(4), c 18.1797(6) Å, β 127.193(2)°, V = 1613.0(1) Å3, R1 = 0.0356 at 180 K. The cell parameters of 2, obtained from neutron powder data at 2 K, are a 11.309(2), b 9.869(1), c 18.201(3) Å, β 127.244(8)°, V = 1617.3(5) Å3. The pore vol. reduces 33-30% by replacing Mn by Co. The material exhibits a diamond framework based on Co-centered CoCo4 tetrahedral nodes, in which all metal ions have octahedral coordination geometry and all HCOO groups link the metal ions in syn-syn/anti modes. It displays thermal stability up to 270°. The compd. easily loses guest mols. without loss of crystallinity, and it partly reabsorbs water from the atm. Significant N2 sorption was obsd. for the desolvated framework suggesting that the material possesses permanent porosity. The magnetic properties show a tendency to a 3-dimensional long-range magnetic ordering, probably antiferromagnetic with a spin canting arrangement <2 K.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXht1Omtb0%253D&md5=344dd2626388f9b496e3d05285ef8edf

      Cubic Octanuclear Ni(II) Clusters in Highly Porous Polypyrazolyl-Based Materials
      Masciocchi, Norberto; Galli, Simona; Colombo, Valentina; Maspero, Angelo; Palmisano, Giovanni; Seyyedi, Behnam; Lamberti, Carlo; Bordiga, Silvia
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (23), 7902-7904CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Two highly porous coordination polymers [Ni8(OH)4(H2O)2(pbp)6] (H2pbp = 4,4'-bis(1H-pyrazol-4-yl)biphenyl) and [Ni8(OH)4(H2O)2(tet)6] (H2tet = 2,6-bis(1H-pyrazol-4-yl)pyrrolo(3,4-J)isoindole-1.3.5.7(2H,6H)-tetrone), contg. rare octanuclear hydroxo-nickel clusters and long bis-pyrazolyl spacers were prepd. and shown to possess, after mild thermal treatment, lattice cavities up to 72% of the total crystal vol. They were characterized by XRD, UV-visible, NIR, XANES, EXAFS and thermodiffractometric studies.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      43
      A Porous Coordination Polymer Assembled from 8-Connected {CoII3(OH)} Clusters and Isonicotinate: Multiple Active Metal Sites, Apical Ligand Substitution, H2 Adsorption, and Magnetism
      Chen, Qing; Lin, Jian-Bin; Xue, Wei; Zeng, Ming-Hua; Chen, Xiao-Ming
      Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2011), 50 (6), 2321-2328CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      A microporous coordination polymer, namely, [Co3(ina)4(OH)(C2H5OH)3](NO3)·C2H5OH·(H2O)3 (1, or MCF-38, ina = isonicotinate), with 8-connected {Co3(OH)} clusters as the structural secondary building units, was solvothermally synthesized. The hydroxo-centered Co(II) cluster involves multiple active metal sites. The interesting apical ligand substitutions were directly obsd., and the corresponding products of [Co3(ina)4(OH)(G)x(H2O)n](NO3)·G·(H2O)m (1 ⊂ PrOH, G = PrOH, x = 2, n = 1, m = 3; 1 ⊂ BuOH, G = BuOH, x = 2, n = 1, m = 1, and 1 ⊂ MeOH, G = MeOH, x = 3, n = 0, m = 7) also were obtained by solvothermal syntheses or crystal-to-crystal transformations. High-pressure H2 adsorption measurement at 77 K reveals that activated 1 can absorb 2.2% H2 at 5 bar. The relative H2 absorption at low pressure (86% of the storage capacity at 1 bar) is higher than the corresponding values reported for some typical porous coordination polymers. The magnetic studies of 1 show a dominant antiferromagnetic coupling between Co(II) ions of intra- and inter-cluster.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      An octacobalt cluster based, (3,12)-connected, magnetic, porous coordination polymer
      Hou, Lei; Zhang, Wei-Xiong; Zhang, Jie-Peng; Xue, Wei; Zhang, Yue-Biao; Chen, Xiao-Ming
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2010), 46 (34), 6311-6313CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Solvothermal reaction of CoSO4 with 2,6-di-p-carboxyphenyl-4,4'-bipyridine affords a novel, octacobalt cluster based, (3,12)-connected porous framework [Co8(μ3-OH)4(SO4)2(dcpbpy)4 (H2O)4]·12DMF·4EtOH·24H2O, which exhibits gas sorption and spin-glassy magnetic behavior.

      Secondary building units, nets and bonding in the chemistry of metal-organic frameworks
      Tranchemontagne, David J.; Mendoza-Cortes, Jose L.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Chemical Society Reviews (2009), 38 (5), 1257-1283CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      This crit. review presents a comprehensive study of transition-metal carboxylate clusters which may serve as secondary building units (SBUs) towards construction and synthesis of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs). We describe the geometries of 131 SBUs, their connectivity and compn. This contribution presents a comprehensive list of the wide variety of transition-metal carboxylate clusters which may serve as secondary building units (SBUs) in the construction and synthesis of metal-org. frameworks. The SBUs discussed here were obtained from a search of mols. and extended structures archived in the Cambridge Structure Database (CSD, version 5.28, Jan. 2007) which included only crystals contg. metal carboxylate linkages (241 refs.).

      47
      Electronic structures of exchange coupled trigonal trimeric Cu(II) complexes: Spin frustration, antisymmetric exchange, pseudo-A terms, and their relation to O2 activation in the multi-copper oxidases
      Yoon, Jungjoo; Solomon, Edward I.
      Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2007), 251 (3+4), 379-400CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. Exchange coupled trinuclear Cu(II) clusters are of great importance in magnetic materials as well as in key steps of biol. catalysis. However, the phys. origins of the unique magnetic and spectroscopic features have been elusive and detailed descriptions of their electronic structures have been limited. In this review, the authors review the recent spectroscopic studies on structurally well-defined trinuclear Cu(II) model complexes with distinct Cu-O bridged structures that represent the 4e- reduced, native intermediate in the catalytic reactivity of the multicopper oxidases. The studies mainly based on ESR and MCD expts. provide new insights into the metal-ligand bonding interactions in the ground and excited states of the exchange coupled Cu(II) trimers: (1) the spin frustrated ground state of an antiferromagnetically coupled Cu(II) trimer undergoes zero-field splitting into 2 doublet states via a 1st-order spin-orbit coupling effect, termed antisym. exchange, that requires effective ground-to-excited state superexchange interactions, and (2) the ligand-to-metal charge transfer excited states undergo coupling interactions via either metal- or ligand-based, single-centered spin-orbit coupling mechanisms. The former is reflected in extremely unusual ground state EPR spectral features, while the latter is manifested in the MCD spectrum of the excited states as a set of 2 field- and temp.-dependent MCD C-terms with opposite signs. This MCD feature, called a pseudo-A term, has allowed differentiation of geometrically distinct Cu-O chromophores of the 2 model complexes and detn. of the structure of the native intermediate in the redn. of O2 to H2O by the multi-copper oxidases. The fundamental descriptions of the electronic structures of exchange coupled Cu(II) trimers implicate their significant roles in the catalytic reductive cleavage of O-O bonds in biol. and in the phys. properties of magnetic materials.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXht1Oqu7Y%253D&md5=ebaf6012606236fd54c1ea632738b65a
    48. 48
      Afrati, T.; Dendrinou-Samara, C.; Raptopoulou, C.; Terzis, A.; Tangoulis, V.; Kessissoglou, D. P. Dalton Trans. 2007, 5156– 5164
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      48
      Copper inverse-9-metallacrown-3 compounds showing antisymmetric magnetic behaviour
      Afrati, Tereza; Dendrinou-Samara, Catherine; Raptopoulou, Catherine; Terzis, Aris; Tangoulis, Vassilis; Kessissoglou, Dimitris P.
      Dalton Transactions (2007), (44), 5156-5164CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The use of Ph 2-pyridyl ketoxime (PhPyCNO)/X- blends (X- = OH-, Cl-, ClO4-) in copper chem. has yielded trinuclear clusters that were characterized as inverse-9-metallacrown-3 accommodating one or two anions. The magnetic behavior showed a large antiferromagnetic interaction. The discrepancy between the Brillouin curve and the expt. was assigned to the influence of the antisym. interaction. By introducing in the magnetization formula the antisym. terms derived from the fitting of the susceptibility data the simulated curve become almost superimposable to the exptl. one. From the EPR findings [Cu3(PhPyCNO)3(OCH3)(Cl)(ClO4)] (1) having isosceles magnetic symmetry or lower (δ ≠ 0), the antisym. exchange is important (G ≠ 0) and ΔE > hv. The structures of the two complexes were detd. by single-crystal x-ray crystallog.

      Spin Frustration in Triangular Cu3II Complexes with 6-Methyl-2-pyridyloxime as Ligand - Synthesis, Structural, and Magnetic Characterization
      Escuer, Albert; Vlahopoulou, Gina; Lloret, Francesc; Mautner, Franz A.
      European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry (2014), 2014 (1), 83-92CODEN: EJICFO; ISSN:1434-1948. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      New examples of μ3-OH/oximato Cu3 triangles have been obtained by treatment of different copper salts with 6-methyl-2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde oxime (6-mepaoH). Depending on the anion, the compds. [Cu3(OH)(6-mepao)3(O2CPh)2] (1), [Cu6(OH)2(6-mepao)6(NO3)3](NO3)·H2O (2·H2O) and [Cu6(OH)2(6-mepao)6(ClO4)3](ClO4) (3) formed and were characterized. Complex 1 is an isolated triangle, whereas 2 and 3 are hexanuclear compds. with two triangular subunits linked by anionic bridges. Susceptibility measurements show very strong antiferromagnetic interactions and the presence of antisym. exchange at low temp. The magnetic properties of these frustrated triangles have been analyzed in terms of susceptibility, magnetization and EPR expts.

      pH dependent facile synthesis of di- and trinuclear oxime based Cu(II) complexes: antiferromagnetic coupling in the dinuclear cores and spin frustration in the triangular core
      Das, Lakshmi Kanta; Drew, Michael G. B.; Diaz, Carmen; Ghosh, Ashutosh
      Dalton Transactions (2014), 43 (20), 7589-7598CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      An oxime based tridentate Schiff base ligand 3-[3-(dimethylamino)propylimino]butan-2-one oxime (HL) produced two dinuclear compds. [Cu2L2(H2O)](ClO4)2 (1) and [Cu2L2(H2O)](BF4)2 (2), and hexanuclear [{Cu3(HL)3(O3ClO)(μ3-O)}2(μ-H)](ClO4)7 (3) when it was reacted with Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O or Cu(BF4)2·6H2O at different pH values. All three compds. were structurally and magnetically characterized. Compds. 1 and 2 are dinuclear species in which the two square planar copper(II) ions are joined solely by the double oximato bridges. However, the hexanuclear compd. 3 consists of two triangular Cu3O cores held together by a proton sepd. by an O···O distance of 2.498(10) Å. The three square pyramidal copper(II) ions at the corners of an isosceles triangle form a triangular core through central oxido (μ3-O) and peripheral oximato bridges. Each triangular Cu3O core is capped by an unusual triply coordinated (μ3-perchlorato-O,O',O'') perchlorate anion. Variable-temp. (2-300 K) magnetic susceptibility measurements show that compds. 1-3 exhibit a strong antiferromagnetic interaction with J values -562.6, -633.1 and -636.0 cm-1, resp. The X-band EPR data at low temp. clearly indicate a spin frustration phenomenon in complex 3.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXntVSmsLk%253D&md5=86422514cb85e42873a3408fbf8d9fb2

      Antisymmetric Exchange in Triangular Tricopper(II) Complexes: Correlation among Structural, Magnetic, and Electron Paramagnetic Resonance Parameters
      Ferrer, Sacramento; Lloret, Francesc; Pardo, Emilio; Clemente-Juan, Juan Modesto; Liu-Gonzalez, Malva; Garcia-Granda, Santiago
      Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 51 (2), 985-1001CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Two new trinuclear copper(II) complexes, [Cu3(μ3-OH)(daat)(Hdat)2(ClO4)2(H2O)3](ClO4)2·2H2O (1) and [Cu3(μ3-OH)(aaat)3(H2O)3](ClO4)2·3H2O (2) (daat = 3,5-diacetylamino-1,2,4-triazolate, Hdat = 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole, and aaat = 3-acetylamino-5-amino-1,2,4-triazolate), have been prepd. from 1,2,4-triazole derivs. and structurally characterized by x-ray crystallog. The structures of 1 and 2 consist of cationic trinuclear copper(II) complexes with a Cu3OH core held by three N,N-triazole bridges between each pair of copper(II) atoms. The copper atoms are five-coordinate with distorted square-pyramidal geometries. The magnetic properties of 1 and 2 and those of five other related 1,2,4-triazolato tricopper(II) complexes with the same triangular structure (3-7) (whose crystal structures were already reported) have been studied at 1.9-300 K. The formulas of 3-7 are [Cu3(μ3-OH)(aaat)3(H2O)3](NO3)2·H2O (3), {[Cu3(μ3-OH)(aat)3(μ3-SO4)]·6H2O}n (4), and [Cu3(μ3-OH)(aat)3A(H2O)2]A·xH2O [A = NO3- (5), CF3SO3- (6), or ClO4- (7); x = 0 or 2] (aat = 3-acetylamino-1,2,4-triazolate). The magnetic and EPR data have been analyzed by using the following isotropic and antisym. exchange Hamiltonian: H = -J[S1S2 + S2S3] - j[S1S3] + G[S1 × S2 + S2 × S3 + S1 × S3]. 1-7 Exhibit strong antiferromagnetic coupling (values for both -J and -j at 210-142 cm-1) and antisym. exchange (G varying from to 27 to 36 cm-1). At low temps., their EPR spectra display high-field (g < 2.0) signals indicating that the triangles present symmetry lower than equilateral and that the antisym. exchange is operative. A magneto-structural study showing a lineal correlation between the Cu-O-Cu angle of the Cu3OH core and the isotropic exchange parameters (J and j) has been conducted. Moreover, a model based on Moriya's theory that allows the prediction of the occurrence of antisym. exchange in the tricopper(II) triangles, via anal. of the overlap between the ground and excited states of the local Cu(II) ions, has been proposed. In addn., anal. expressions for evaluating both the isotropic and antisym. exchange parameters from the exptl. magnetic susceptibility data of triangular complexes with local spins (S) of 1/2, 3/2, or 5/2 have been purposely derived. Finally, the magnetic and EPR results of this work are discussed and compared with those of other tricopper(II) triangles reported in the literature.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhs1OjurrJ&md5=962a47cfb59002ea5272a096ff95835d

      Solid State Coordination Chemistry of the Copper(II)/Pyridyl- and Pyrazine-Tetrazolate/Sulfate System
      Darling, Kari; Ouellette, Wayne; Prosvirin, Andrey; Freund, Steven; Dunbar, Kim R.; Zubieta, Jon
      Crystal Growth & Design (2012), 12 (5), 2662-2672CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      Hydrothermal reactions of Cu(SO4)·5H2O with pyridyl- and pyrazine-substituted tetrazoles provided a series of materials of the Cu(II)/imine-tetrazolate/SO42- class. [Cu3(OH)(H2O)3(3-pyrHtet-O)3(SO4)] (1) (3-pyrHtet-O = 2-hydroxy-3-Hpyridyltetrazolate) is mol. and exhibits the common {Cu3(μ3-OH)}5+ core. In addn., the pyridyl group of the ligand has been hydroxylated to the to the 2-hydroxy-3-Hpyridyltetrazole form. While the two-dimensional [Cu3(OH)2(H2O)3(3-pyrtet)2(SO4)] (2) also contains the {Cu3(μ3-OH)}5+, the 3-pyrtet ligands (3-pyridyltetrazolate) project outward from the cluster core to link to adjacent clusters in forming the network connectivity. The two-dimensional (Me2NH2)[Cu(2-pyrtet)(SO4)] (3) exhibits binuclear building units {Cu2(2-pyrtet)}2+ that link to adjacent units through the sulfato groups. In contrast, the pyrazinetetrazolate deriv., [Cu4(pyrztet)6(H2O)2(SO4)] (4), is constructed from {Cu4(tetrazolate)6(H2O)2(SO4)}n chains linked through the pyrazinetetrazolate ligands into a three-dimensional framework. The magnetic properties of the compds. reflect these structural characteristics.

      Trinuclear, Tetranuclear, and Polymeric CuII Complexes from the First Use of 2-Pyridylcyanoxime in Transition Metal Chemistry: Synthetic, Structural, and Magnetic Studies
      Escuer, Albert; Vlahopoulou, Gina; Perlepes, Spyros P.; Mautner, Franz A.
      Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2011), 50 (6), 2468-2478CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      The first use of 2-pyridylcyanoxime, (py)C(CN)NOH, in transition metal chem. is described. Depending on the nature of the metal starting material and the reaction conditions employed, the CuII/(py)C(CN)NOH system provided access to complexes [Cu3O{(py)C(CN)NO}3(NO3)(H2O)2(MeOH)] (1), [Cu4O{(py)C(CN)NO}4(O2CMe)2] (2), [Cu4(OH)2{(py)C(CN)NO}2(O2CPh)4]2n·n[Cu4(OH)2{(py)C(CN)NO}2(O2CPh)4] (3), and [Cu{(py)C(CN)NO}2]n (4). The mol. of 1 consists of three CuII atoms in a strictly equilateral arrangement bridged by a central μ3-oxide group. The mol. of 2 consists of a tetrahedron of CuII atoms held together by a central μ4-oxide ion, four η1:η1:η1:μ-(py)C(CN)NO- ligands and two η1:η1:μ-MeCO2- groups. The crystal structure of 3 consists of [Cu4(OH)2{(py)C(CN)NO}2(O2CPh)4]2n double chains and discrete cluster [Cu4(OH)2{(py)C(CN)NO}2(O2CPh)4] mols. The crystal structure of 4 consists of neutral polymeric chains based on centrosym. mononuclear [Cu{(py)C(CN)NO}2] units. The CuII atoms are doubly bridged by the oximate groups of two η1:η1:η1:μ-(py)C(CN)NO- ligands. Variable-temp., solid-state d.c. magnetic susceptibility studies were carried out for 1-4. The data indicate very strong antiferromagnetic exchange interactions for 1-3. The obtained J values are discussed in depth on the basis of the structural parameters of the complexes, literature reports, and existing magnetostructural correlations.

      Spin frustration in a Cu(II)3 triangle frustrated?
      Anwar, Muhammad U.; Thompson, Laurence K.; Dawe, Louise N.
      Dalton Transactions (2011), 40 (7), 1437-1440CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A new, crystallog. characterized spiral hexanuclear antiferromagnetic Cu(II) complex with a [Cu3(μ2-NO)3(μ3-O)] triangular core, [Cu6L3(μ3-OH)(NO3)5(CH3OH)3][Cu6L3(μ3-O)(NO3)4(CH3OH)3(H2O)]·5H2O (H2L = 2-(hydroxyimino)propanoic acid 2-(2-pyridinylmethylene)hydrazide, I) has direct metal spin coupling through diazine (μ2-NN), oxime (μ2-NO) and oxide/hydroxide (μ3-O) bridges. Spin frustration, expected in the triangular core, is suppressed (frustrated) by the bridging antiferromagnetic connections to the external metals, and so any residual spin in the triangle effectively cannot be stabilized. Crystal data: triclinic, P‾1, a = 16.1537(17), b = 16.6970(12), c = 23.612(2) Å, α = 70.172(10)°, β = 82.242(12)°, γ = 67.126(9)°, Z = 2, 16,645 obsd. reflections with I > 2σ(I), R1 = 0.1087, wR2 = 0.3498.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhtlOjsLw%253D&md5=915ede41a22cd0ff438243b87d768790

      Solid-State Coordination Chemistry of Copper(II) Tetrazolates: Anion Control of Frameworks Constructed from Trinuclear Copper(II) Building Blocks
      Ouellette, Wayne; Liu, Hongxue; O'Connor, Charles J.; Zubieta, Jon
      Inorganic Chemistry (2009), 48 (11), 4655-4657CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      The products of the reactions of Cu(II) starting materials with 4-pyridyltetrazole (4-Hpt) in DMF/MeOH solns. are detd. by the anion identity and concn. In the absence of chloride, the 3-dimensional open-framework material [Cu3(OH)3(4-pt)3(DMF)4]·5DMF·3MeOH (1·5DMF·3MeOH) is isolated, while variations in the chloride concn. yield the 2-dimensional and 3-dimensional materials, [Cu3Cl4(4-pt)2(4Hpt)2]·4DMF·2MeOH (2) and [Cu3Cl2(4-pt)4]·4DMF·4MeOH (3), resp. All three structures exhibit trinuclear Cu(II) building blocks: the triangular {Cu3(μ3-OH)}5+ core in 1 and {Cu3Cl4(4-pt)4(4-Hpt)2}2- and {Cu3Cl2(4-pt)8}4- chains in 2 and 3, resp. All three materials display microporosity, which is highly dependent on the method of sample prepn.

      Afrati, T.; Dendrinou-Samara, C.; Raptopoulou, C.; Terzis, A.; Tangoulis, V.; Tsipis, A.; Kessissoglou, D. P. Inorg. Chem. 2008, 47, 7545– 7555
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      56
      Experimental and Theoretical Study of the Antisymmetric Magnetic Behavior of Copper inverse-9-Metallacrown-3 Compounds
      Afrati, Tereza; Dendrinou-Samara, Catherine; Raptopoulou, Catherine; Terzis, Aris; Tangoulis, Vassilis; Tsipis, Athanassios; Kessissoglou, Dimitris P.
      Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2008), 47 (17), 7545-7555CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Use of PhPyCNO-/X- blends (PhPyCNOH = Ph 2-pyridyl ketoxime; X- = OH-, alkanoato, ClO4-) in Cu chem. yielded trinuclear clusters that were characterized as inverse-9-metallacrown-3 compds. and accommodate one or two guest ligands. The magnetic behavior showed a large antiferromagnetic interaction and a discrepancy between the low-temp. magnetic behavior obsd. exptl. and that predicted from a magnetic model. The discrepancy between the Brillouin curve and the exptl. result provides clear evidence of the influence of the antisym. interaction. Introducing the antisym. terms derived from the fit of the susceptibility data into the magnetization formula caused the simulated curve to become nearly superimposable on the exptl. one. The EPR data indicated that [Cu3(PhPyCNO)3(μ3-OH)(2,4,5-T)2] (1), where 2,4,5-T is 2,4,5-trichlorophenoxyacetate, has isosceles or lower magnetic symmetry (δ ≠ 0), that antisym. exchange is important (G ≠ 0), and that ΔE > hν. The structures of the complexes 1 and [Cu3(PhPyCNO)3(μ3-OH)(H2O)(ClO4)2] (2) were detd. using single-crystal x-ray crystallog. Theor. calcns. based on d. functional theory were performed using the full crystal structures of 1, 2, [Cu3(PhPyCNO)3(OH)(MeOH)2(ClO4)2] (3), and [Cu3(PhPyCNO)3(μ3-OMe)(Cl)(ClO4)] (4). The geometries of the model compds. [Cu3(κ3N,N,O-HNCHCHNO)3(μ3-OH)(μ2-HCOO)(HCOO)] (5), [Cu3(κ3N,N,O-HNCHCHNO)3(μ2-HCOO)(HCOO)]+ (6), [Cu3(κ3N,N,O-HNCHCHNO)3(μ3-O)]+ (7), and [Cu3(κ3N,N,O-HNCHCHNO)3]3+ (8) were optimized at the same level of theory for both the doublet and quartet states, and vibrational anal. indicated that the resulting equil. geometries corresponded to min. on the potential energy surfaces. Both eg and t2g magnetic orbitals seem to contribute to the magnetic exchange coupling. The latter contribution, although less important, might be due to overlap of the t2g orbitals with the p-type orbitals of the central triply bridging oxide ligand, thereby affecting its displacement from the Cu3 plane and contributing to the antiferromagnetic coupling. The crucial role of the triply bridging oxide (μ3-O) ligand on the antiferromagnetic exchange coupling between the three Cu(II) magnetic centers is further evidenced by the excellent linear correlation of the coupling const. J with the distance of the μ3-O ligand from the centroid of the Cu3 triangle.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXptlCjtrk%253D&md5=9f64ebea2c1b861d02189168783c26f4
    57. 57
      Ding, B.; Yi, L.; Cheng, P.; Liao, D.-Z.; Yan, S.-P. Inorg. Chem. 2006, 45, 5799– 5803
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      57
      Synthesis and Characterization of a 3D Coordination Polymer Based on Trinuclear Triangular CuII as Secondary Building Units
      Ding, Bin; Yi, Long; Cheng, Peng; Liao, Dai-Zheng; Yan, Shi-Ping
      Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (15), 5799-5803CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      The hydrothermal reaction of CuII salts with 1,2,4-triazole (Htrz) in aq. NH3 yielded a novel metal-org. framework {[Cu3(μ3-O)(μ3-trz)3(OH)(H2O)6]}n (1), which was characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction, x-ray powder diffraction, TGA, IR, and variable-temp. magnetic susceptibility. It crystallizes in cubic, space group Fd‾3c with a 24.644(3) Å, and Z = 96. Its framework is the 1st 3-dimensional structure using coordinative interactions constructed via trinuclear triangular CuII secondary building units, in which both CuII ions and trz ligands act as three-connected nodes to form a 6.82 net. An overall antiferromagnetic behavior was found in the compd.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XlvFShs74%253D&md5=8e3ee796ca4313d195871fc2e371fed6

      Ferrer, S.; Lloret, F.; Bertomeu, I.; Alzuet, G.; Borras, J.; Garcia-Granda, S.; Liu-Gonzalez, M.; Haasnoot, J. G. Inorg. Chem. 2002, 41, 5821– 5830
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      58
      Cyclic Trinuclear and Chain of Cyclic Trinuclear Copper(II) Complexes Containing a Pyramidal Cu3O(H) Core. Crystal Structures and Magnetic Properties of [Cu3(μ3-OH)(aaat)3(H2O)3](NO3)2·H2O [aaat = 3-acetylamino-5-amino-1,2,4-triazolate] and {[Cu3(μ3-OH)(aat)3(μ3-SO4)]·6H2O}n [aat = 3-acetylamino-1,2,4-triazolate]: New Cases of Spin-Frustrated Systems
      Ferrer, Sacramento; Lloret, Francesc; Bertomeu, Ignacio; Alzuet, Gloria; Borras, Joaquin; Garcia-Granda, Santiago; Liu-Gonzalez, Malva; Haasnoot, Jaap G.
      Inorganic Chemistry (2002), 41 (22), 5821-5830CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      New cyclic trinuclear Cu(II) complexes with 1,2,4-triazole ligands, [Cu3(μ3-OH)(aaat)3(H2O)3](NO3)2·H2O [Haaat = 3-acetylamino-5-amino-1,2,4-triazole] (1) and {[Cu3(μ3-OH)(aat)3(μ3-SO4)]·6H2O}n [Haat = 3-acetylamino-1,2,4-triazole] (2), were prepd. and characterized by x-ray crystallog. and magnetic measurements. Compd. 1, the first reported with the ligand (H)aaat, consists of discrete trinuclear cations, assocd. NO3- anions and lattice H2O mols. Compd. 2 consists of unusual chains of trinuclear units with a tridentate sulfato group linking the trimeric units and H2O mols. stabilizing the crystal lattice. In both complexes 1 and 2, the trinuclear [Cu3(OH)L3] unit contains a pyramidal Cu3-μ3-OH core, and an almost flat Cu3N6 ring formed by the N,N-bridging triazolato groups. The Cu...Cu' intratrimeric distances are 3.35-3.37-3.39 Å in 1 and 3.34-3.34-3.36 Å in 2. The Cu atoms are five-coordinated with a distorted square-pyramidal geometry. Magnetic measurements were performed in the 1.9-300 K temp. range. In the high-temp. region (T > 90 K), exptl. data could be satisfactorily reproduced by using an isotropic exchange model, H = -J(S1S2 + S2S3 + S1S3), with J = -194.6 cm-1 and g = 2.08 for 1, and J = -185.1 cm-1 and g = 2.10 for 2. The magnitude of the antiferromagnetic exchange in both complexes is discussed from their structural features by comparison with reported N,N-periphery-bridged trinuclear systems. To fit the exptl. magnetic data at low temp., an antisym. exchange term, HAS = G(S1xS2 + S2xS3 + S1xS3), had to be introduced, with G = 27.8(1) and 31.0(2) cm-1. Crystal data: C12H27Cu3N17O14 (1) (MW = 824.13) crystallizes in triclinic space group, P‾1, Z = 2, with a 8.852(2), b 11.491(3), c 15.404(3) Å, α 70.43(3), β 75.11(2), γ 88.43(2)°, dc = 1.922 g cm-3, with final agreement values R1 = 0.0822 and wR2 = 0.2300 for 4989 unique reflections; C12H28Cu3N12O14S (2) (MW = 787.14) crystallizes in triclinic space group, P‾1, Z = 2, with a 7.146(6), b 14.26(1), c 15.35(2) Å, α 109.0(9), β 93.6(9), γ 99.5(7)°, dc = 1.806 g cm-3, with final agreement values R1 = 0.0628 and wR2 = 0.1571 for 3997 obsd. reflections. The antisym. exchange obsd. reinforces the hypothesis that coplanarity between coordination basal planes of the interconnected Cu(II) atoms is not the decisive factor in the magnitude of the antiferromagnetic exchange within the Cu3O cluster.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38Xns1ykurY%253D&md5=9c4bc7f92c6ab95e0526f76f7af87b82

      Two Unusual 3D Copper(II) Coordination Polymers Constructed by p-Sulfonated Calixarenes and Bis(triazolyl) Ligands
      Chen, Chun; Ma, Jian-Fang; Liu, Bo; Yang, Jin; Liu, Ying-Ying
      Crystal Growth & Design (2011), 11 (10), 4491-4497CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      Two novel Cu(II) compds. [Cu2(btb)3.5(C4AS)(H2O)]·2.5(H2O) (1) and [Cu2.5(btp)2(C4AS)(htz)(H2O)3]·4.75(H2O) (2) were hydrothermally synthesized and structurally detd. by single-crystal x-ray diffraction analyses (btb = 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane, btp = 1,5-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)pentane, htz = 1,3,4-triazolate, and C4AS = p-sulfonato-calix[4]arene). In 1, the btb ligands connect Cu(II) atoms to form a 3D porous framework. The 1D chains constructed by C4AS and Cu(II) atoms are further bonded to the 3D porous framework through the Cu-O bonds. Topol., structure 1 belongs to a 3D (3,6)-connected net with the Schlafli symbol of (42·6)(46·68·8). In 2, the C4AS links the Cu(II) atoms to form 1D chains, which are further connected by the btp and htz to generate a 3D (3,4,6)-connected framework with the Schlafli symbol of (62·8)(52·62·7.8)(54·62·7.87·9). The two compds. were further characterized by IR spectra (IR), elemental analyses, powder x-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermogravimetric (TG) analyses, and UV-visible absorption spectra.

      Systematic Synthesis of a Metal Organic Framework Based on Triangular Cu3(μ3-OH) Secondary Building Units: From a 0-D Complex to a 1-D Chain and a 3-D Lattice
      Rivera-Carrillo, Marlyn; Chakraborty, Indranil; Raptis, Raphael G.
      Crystal Growth & Design (2010), 10 (6), 2606-2612CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      Reactions of Cu(CF3SO3)2 and pyrazole in methanolic solns. in the presence of stoichiometric amts. of pyridine (py), py/4,4'-bipyridine (4,4'-bpy), or 4,4'-bpy have yielded two new complexes [Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-pz)3(py)3](CF3SO3)2·0.5H2O (1) and [{Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-pz)3(py)2}2(μ-4,4'-bpy)](CF3SO3)4 (2), a one-dimensional coordination polymer, {[Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-pz)3(py)(μ-4,4'-bpy)](CF3SO3)2·0.5H2O}n (3), and a three-dimensional, 8-fold interpenetrated extended lattice, {[Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-pz)3(μ-4,4'-bpy)1.5](CF3SO3)2·1.5H2O}n (4).

      Cation-exchange porosity tuning in anionic metal-organic frameworks for the selective separation of gases and vapors and for catalysis
      Quartapelle Procopio, Elsa; Linares, Fatima; Montoro, Carmen; Colombo, Valentina; Maspero, Angelo; Barea, Elisa; Navarro, Jorge A. R.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2010), 49 (40), 7308-7311, S7308/1-S7308/10CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Ammonium copper(II) 4-carboxypyrazolato framework NH4[Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ3-C4H2N2O2)3]·15H2O, NH4@1, was prepd. and characterized by X-ray diffraction. The sepn. efficiency of complex mixts. of gases (acetylene, carbon dioxide, methane, nitrogen) and vapors (benzene, cyclohexane) by adsorption on A[Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ3-4-carboxypyrazolato)3] (A@1) metal-org. frameworks depends on temp. and the extra-framework cation A (A = Li+, K+, Ca2+, La3+, Me3NH+, Et3NH+). NH4@1 also behaves as an oxidn. catalyst.

      Naik, A. D.; Dirtu, M. M.; Leonard, A.; Tinant, B.; Marchand-Brynaert, J.; Su, B.-L.; Garcia, Y. Cryst. Growth Des. 2010, 10, 1798– 1807
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      64
      Engineering Three-Dimensional Chains of Porous Nanoballs from a 1,2,4-Triazole-carboxylate Supramolecular Synthon
      Naik, Anil D.; Dirtu, Marinela M.; Leonard, Alexandre; Tinant, Bernard; Marchand-Brynaert, Jacqueline; Su, Bao-Lian; Garcia, Yann
      Crystal Growth & Design (2010), 10 (4), 1798-1807CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      Glycine Et ester was recruited in an amine exchange process based on a transamination to afford Et 4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl-acetate (L1). The acid hydrolysis of this mol. leads to quant. isolation of 4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl acetic acid (L2). This versatile synthon crystallizes in a noncentrosym. orthorhombic space group (Fdd2) with Z = 16. This crystal structure is the first one for a 1,2,4-triazole ligand constructed from an amino acid deriv. The strong intermol. hydrogen bonding O-H···N (2.570(3) Å) connects mols. into infinite one-dimensional chains running parallel to the b axis, and the structure is further extended by numerous but moderate strength hydrogen bonds (C-H···O). Prominent features of L2 are the presence of diverse potential coordinating groups such as carboxylic acid and triazole on the same framework as well as the inherent flexibility of the ligand backbone. Reaction of L1 or L2 with aq. Cu(BF4)2 in aq. DMF gives dark blue crystals which crystallize in a noncentrosym., cubic space group (I43m) and which were formulated as [Cu3(μ3-O)(L2)3·(H2O)3]BF4·H2O (C1). The self-assembly of C3-sym., μ3-oxo bridged triangular tricopper secondary building blocks (SBB) formed an unique architecture which encompasses voluminous nanoball voids of 1 nm. The total solvent accessible vol. is 4477.5 Å3 which accounts for 48% of the cell vol. The crystal network stability was studied by thermogravimetric anal. TGA-DTA and SEM analyses. Sorption properties and gas storage capacities were measured by BET. C1 shows no preference for N2(g), but a reversible H2(g) uptake of 21 cm3/g was obsd. Morphol. anal. by SEM on single crystals of C1 shows "ultrawells" of square shape irregularly located on the surface, whose origin is due to desolvation or crystal defects. Mercury porosimetry measurements reveal pore size distribution with a diam. ranging from 350 nm to 2.3 μm.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXjs1OitbY%253D&md5=5ea5d9fc5dcde40fcc0607a3c181f969
    65. 65

      Design of Novel Three-Dimensional Coordination Polymers Based on Triangular Trinuclear Copper 1,2,4-Triazolate Units
      Zhai, Quan-Guo; Lu, Can-Zhong; Chen, Shu-Mei; Xu, Xin-Jiang; Yang, Wen-Bin
      Crystal Growth & Design (2006), 6 (6), 1393-1398CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      By controlling the molar ratios of Cu dichloride dihydrate and 1,2,4-triazole (trz), the authors generated novel three-dimensional coordination polymers constructed from μ3-oxo or μ3-Cl triangular Cu units, exhibiting six-connected porous self-penetrating net, graphite layer, and inorg.-org. hybrid network structures, resp. The prepn. and crystal structure of [Cu3(μ3-O)(μ3-trz)3]2[OH]2·15H2O (1), Cu[Cu3(μ3-O)(μ3-trz)3Cl3] (2) and [Cu2(μ3-trz)(μ3-Cl)2] (3) are reported.

      Ouellette, Wayne; Yu, Ming Hui; O'Connor, Charles J.; Hagrman, Douglas; Zubieta, Jon
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2006), 45 (21), 3497-3500CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Three new compds. contg. networks of CuI or CuII ions linked by 1,2,4-triazolate (trz) ligands were prepd. by hydrothermal synthesis. The microporous metalorg. framework {Cu3(μ3-OH)(trz)3(OH)2(H2O)4}n, which is built up from magnetic triangles, forms 17 × 13 × 13 Å3 cavities.

      A flexible porous metal-azolate framework constructed by [Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ2-O)(triazolate)2]+ building blocks. Synthesis, reversible structural transformation and related magnetic properties
      Xia, Bing; Chen, Zhenxia; Zheng, Qingshu; Zheng, Hua; Deng, Mingli; Ling, Yun; Weng, Linhong; Zhou, Yaming
      CrystEngComm (2013), 15 (17), 3484-3489CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A 3D porous structure of [Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ2-O)(dmtrz)2(HCOO)(μ2-H2O)(H2O)3]·H2O (1) was in situ solvothermally synthesized. In 1, the trinuclear triangular [Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ2-O)(dmtrz)2] cluster connects itself infinitely, resulting in the type-II channel structure, which is different from that of the rigid type-I channel structure reported previously. Reversible dehydration and rehydration induced crystal-to-amorphous-like phase transformation for structure 1 was obsd. and confirmed by PXRD patterns and gas adsorption. Furthermore, as a response to the structural transformation, the stimuli-induced modulation of magnetic properties were obsd.

      A Porous Metal-Organic Framework Constructed from Carboxylate-Pyrazolate Shared Heptanuclear Zinc Clusters: Synthesis, Gas Adsorption, and Guest-Dependent Luminescent Properties
      Zheng, Qingshu; Yang, Feilong; Deng, Mingli; Ling, Yun; Liu, Xiaofeng; Chen, Zhenxia; Wang, Yunhua; Weng, Linhong; Zhou, Yaming
      Inorganic Chemistry (2013), 52 (18), 10368-10374CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      A three-dimensional porous structure of [Zn7O2(bpdc)4(dmpp)2]·6DEF·10H2O (MAC-7, H2bpdc = 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid, Hdmpp = 3,5-dimethyl-4-(4'-pyridyl)-pyrazole), built of 12-bridged carboxylate-pyrazolate shared Zn7O2 clusters, was synthesized. Because of the presence of 12-bridged carboxylate-pyrazolate shared building block, MAC-7 is a double-linked pcu-type framework and shows reversible phase transformation. Photoluminescent property studies indicate that MAC-7 could sense nitrobenzene over toluene, p-xylene, and mesitylene by luminescent quenching.

      Yang, F. L.; Zheng, Q. S.; Chen, Z. X.; Ling, Y.; Liu, X. F.; Weng, L. H.; Zhou, Y. M. CrystEngComm 2013, 15, 7031

      69
      A three-dimensional structure built of paddle-wheel and triazolate-dinuclear metal clusters: synthesis, deformation and reformation of paddle-wheel unit in the single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation
      Yang, Feilong; Zheng, Qingshu; Chen, Zhenxia; Ling, Yun; Liu, Xiaofeng; Weng, Linhong; Zhou, Yaming
      CrystEngComm (2013), 15 (35), 7031-7037CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Solvothermal reaction of [1,1'-biphenyl]-3,3',5,5'-tetracarboxylic acid (H4bptc), 3,5-diamino-1H-1,2,4-triazole (Hdatrz) and zinc acetate affords a three-dimensional structure of [Zn2(bptc)(datrz)]Me2NH2·2H2O (MAC-6). It is a (3,6)-connected framework built of paddle-wheel and triazolate-dinuclear metal clusters together with bptc ligands, and shows a novel (42.6)2(44.66.85) topol. Heating crystal samples of MAC-6 leads to the structure transformation to [Zn2(bptc)(datrz)(H2O)0.5]Me2NH2·H2O (MAC-6'), in which the paddle-wheel unit deforms to a dinuclear unit. Remarkably, MAC-6' can reversibly recover to MAC-6 when the samples of MAC-6' were immersed into DMF. The deformation and reformation of the paddle-wheel unit were studied by single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) transformation. Their photoluminescent properties were also studied.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      70
      Novel Iso-Reticular Zn(II) Metal-Organic Frameworks constructed by Trinuclear-Triangular and Paddle-Wheel Units: Synthesis, Structure and Gas Adsorption
      Ling, Yun; Yang, Feilong; Deng, Mingli; Chen, Zhenxia; Liu, Xiaofeng; Weng, Linhong; Zhou, Yaming
      Dalton Transactions (2012), 41 (14), 4007-4011CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Two novel Zn(II) metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) constructed by trinuclear-triangular and paddle-wheel units, namely {[Zn5(dmtrz)3(IPA)3(OH)]·DMF·H2O}n (MAC-4, Hdmtrz = 3,5-dimethyl-1H-1,2,4-triazole, H2IPA = isophthalic acid, DMF = DMF) and {[Zn5(dmtrz)3(OH-IPA)3(OH)]·DMF·5H2O}n (MAC-4-OH, OH-H2IPA = 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid), were solvothermally synthesized. Single-crystal analyses reveal that MAC-4-OH is an iso-reticular framework of MAC-4 with channels functionalized by hydroxyl groups. Gas adsorption reveals that MAC-4-OH shows a significant enhancement for CO2 uptake compared with that of MAC-4 due to the existence of electrostatic attractive interactions, though its surface area is lower than that of MAC-4.

      A zinc(II) metal-organic framework based on triazole and dicarboxylate ligands for selective adsorption of hexane isomers
      Ling, Yun; Chen, Zhen-Xia; Zhai, Fu-Peng; Zhou, Ya-Ming; Weng, Lin-Hong; Zhao, Dong-Yuan
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2011), 47 (25), 7197-7199CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)

      Two Novel Zinc(II) Metal-Organic Frameworks Based on Triazole-Carboxylate Shared Paddle-Wheel Units: Synthesis, Structure, and Gas Adsorption
      Ling, Yun; Chen, Zhenxia; Zheng, Hua; Zhou, Yaming; Weng, Linhong; Zhao, Dongyuan
      Crystal Growth & Design (2011), 11 (7), 2811-2816CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      Two novel porous metal-org. frameworks {Zn7(btc)4(dmtrz)2(H2O)5}n (1) and {[Zn6(btc)4(dmtrz)3]·3H3O·2H2O}n (2) (H3btc = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid, Hdmtrz = 3,5-dimethyl-1H-1,2,4-triazole) were solvothermally synthesized. Single-crystal structure anal. reveals that both structure 1 and 2 contain special triazole-carboxylate shared paddle-wheel units. The crucial factors to the assembly of such paddle-wheel units are discussed. Gas adsorption studies suggest that 2 is a potential microporous material for adsorptive sepn. of CO2 over N2.

      A novel green phosphorescent silver(I) coordination polymer with 3-fold interpenetrated CdSO4-type net generated via in situ reaction
      Ling, Yun; Chen, Zhen-Xia; Zhou, Ya-Ming; Weng, Lin-Hong; Zhao, Dong-Yuan
      CrystEngComm (2011), 13 (5), 1504-1508CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A novel 3D [Ag3(dmtrz)2(CN)]n (Hdmtrz = 3,5-dimethyl-1H-1,2,4-triazole) (I) with a 3-fold interpenetrated CdSO4-type net is in situ solvothermal synthesized, and influential factors in the in situ reaction are briefly discussed. The luminescent property studies reveal that I shows green phosphorescent emission upon excitation while other binary Ag(I)-dmtrz compds. discussed in this paper only emit blue phosphorescence. The crystal structure of I and 2 other prepd. Ag complexes with 3,5-dimethyl-1H-1,2,4-triazole were studied.

      Relaying Isomerism from Ligands to Metal Complexes: Synthesis and Structures of Four Isomeric Binary Silver(I) 3,5-Dibutyl-1,2,4-triazolates
      Yang, Guang; Duan, Peng-Cheng; Shi, Kai-Ge; Raptis, Raphael G.
      Crystal Growth & Design (2012), 12 (4), 1882-1889CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      Four isomers of 3,5-dibutyl-1H-1,2,4-triazole (3,5-R2tzH, R = Bu, iso-Bu (iBu), sec-Bu (sBu), and tert-Bu (tBu)) were synthesized by condensation of the corresponding org. acids and hydrazine, followed by a deamination reaction. Their binary silver complexes were prepd. and structurally characterized by x-ray diffraction. [Ag(3,5-Bu2tz)]n and [Ag(3,5-iBu2tz)]n exhibit 3-dimensional structures of cds and dia topologies, resp., while [Ag(3,5-sBu2tz)]n displays a 2-dimensional sql net and [Ag(3,5-tBu2tz)]4 is a 0-dimensional tetranuclear complex. Having the same empirical formula, these four binary silver triazolates are true isomers, differing in their linkage and triazole coordination modes. This work represents an interesting case in which ligand isomerism is manifested in the structures of the corresponding metal complexes.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XjtVGgsLw%253D&md5=44d1932e2b5afecee386efb10d7e4ac9

      A short history of SHELX
      Sheldrick, George M.
      Acta Crystallographica, Section A: Foundations of Crystallography (2008), 64 (1), 112-122CODEN: ACACEQ; ISSN:0108-7673. (International Union of Crystallography)
      An account is given of the development of the SHELX system of computer programs from SHELX-76 to the present day. In addn. to identifying useful innovations that have come into general use through their implementation in SHELX, a crit. anal. is presented of the less-successful features, missed opportunities and desirable improvements for future releases of the software. An attempt is made to understand how a program originally designed for photog. intensity data, punched cards and computers over 10000 times slower than an av. modern personal computer has managed to survive for so long. SHELXL is the most widely used program for small-mol. refinement and SHELXS and SHELXD are often employed for structure soln. despite the availability of objectively superior programs. SHELXL also finds a niche for the refinement of macromols. against high-resoln. or twinned data; SHELXPRO acts as an interface for macromol. applications. SHELXC, SHELXD and SHELXE are proving useful for the exptl. phasing of macromols., esp. because they are fast and robust and so are often employed in pipelines for high-throughput phasing. This paper could serve as a general literature citation when one or more of the open-source SHELX programs (and the Bruker AXS version SHELXTL) are employed in the course of a crystal-structure detn.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhsVGhurzO&md5=8f91f10be4a9df74b2a9dad522c71e6e

      Solvothermal in situ formation of a hexanuclear copper(I) complex with 2-thiolate-N,N-dimethylnicotinamide
      Du, Miao; Zou, Ru-Qiang; Zhong, Rui-Qin; Xu, Qiang
      Inorganic Chemistry Communications (2007), 10 (12), 1437-1439CODEN: ICCOFP; ISSN:1387-7003. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Solvothermal reaction of 2-mercaptonicotinic acid (HL1) with Cu(II) nitrate in DMF/MeOH medium gives a novel hexanuclear complex, [Cu(L2)]6·(H2O)2 (1), in which in situ formation of an anionic ligand N,N-dimethylnicotinamide-2-thiolate (L2) and redn. of Cu(II) to Cu(I) are obsd. X-ray single-crystal structure of 1 reveals that each Cu(I) center adopts a trigonal geometry provided by two thiolate and one pyridyl groups from three sepd. L2 ligands. As a result, six Cu(I) ions are interconnected by six μ3-L2 bridges to afford a hexanuclear cluster, in which the octahedral Cu6 core is stabilized by significant cuprophilic interactions.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      A Microporous Metal-Organic Framework with Immobilized -OH Functional Groups within the Pore Surfaces for Selective Gas Sorption
      Chen, Zhenxia; Xiang, Shengchang; Arman, Hadi D.; Li, Peng; Tidrow, Steven; Zhao, Dongyuan; Chen, Banglin
      European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry (2010), (24), 3745-3749CODEN: EJICFO; ISSN:1434-1948. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A new two-dimensional microporous metal-org. framework Cu(BDC-OH)(H2O)·0.5DEF [abbreviation: Cu(BDC-OH); H2BDC-OH = 2-hydroxybenzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid; DEF = diethylformamide] with functional OH groups on the pore surfaces was solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized. The activated Cu(BDC-OH) exhibits a moderate Langmuir surface of 584 m2g-1, a pore vol. of 0.214 cm3g-1, and C2H2/CH4 and CO2/CH4 selectivity of 6.7 and 9.3, resp., at 296 K, thereby highlighting the promise for its application in gas sepn.

      Theoretical Investigation on Triagonal Symmetry Copper Trimers: Magneto-Structural Correlation and Spin Frustration
      Wang, Li-Li; Sun, You-Min; Yu, Zhang-Yu; Qi, Zhong-Nan; Liu, Cheng-Bu
      Journal of Physical Chemistry A (2009), 113 (39), 10534-10539CODEN: JPCAFH; ISSN:1089-5639. (American Chemical Society)
      The mechanisms of the magnetic coupling interactions for two trigonal-bipyramid trinuclear Cu(II) complexes Cu3(μ3-X)2(μ-pz)3X3 (X = Cl and Br, resp.) and three trigonal trinuclear Cu(II) complexes Cu3(μ3-X)(μ-pz)3Cl3 (X = Cl, Br, and O) are investigated by the calcns. based on d. functional theory combined with broken-symmetry approach (DFT-BS). The research on the magneto-structural correlation reveals that the magnetic coupling interaction is sensitive to the Cu-(μ3-X)-Cu angle. With the Cu-(μ3-X)-Cu angle changing from 76 to 120°, the magnetic coupling interaction is switched from ferromagnetic to antiferromagnetic. According to the anal. of the MOs and the variation of the spin-state energies vs. the ratio of the magnetic coupling consts., it is found that there exists spin frustration phenomenon in these complexes.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtFSgu7nP&md5=04e319cb34115627a907992084098956

      Sumida, K.; Rogow, D. L.; Mason, J. A.; McDonald, T. M.; Bloch, E. D.; Herm, Z. R.; Bae, T. H.; Long, J. R. Chem. Rev. 2012, 112, 724– 781
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Carbon Dioxide Capture in Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Sumida, Kenji; Rogow, David L.; Mason, Jarad A.; McDonald, Thomas M.; Bloch, Eric D.; Herm, Zoey R.; Bae, Tae-Hyun; Long, Jeffrey R.
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 724-781CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      An extensive review is given on progress made in the capture of CO2 from power plant emissions, briefly considering also the CO2 storage (sequestration) of the enormous quantities of CO2 that would be obtained as a result of a successful capture framework. The main existing CO2 capture technologies are discussed in the context of capture performance considerations of aq. alkanolamine solns. and porous solids such as zeolites and activated carbons. Schematic diagrams are presented of idealized temp. swing adsorption, pressure swing adsorption, and vacuum swing adsorption processes for regenerating solid adsorbent in a fixed-bed column. The structural features and CO2 adsorption characteristics of isoreticular metal-org. frameworks (MOF) are discussed in detail. The high-pressure adsorption capacities of 36 MOF and the lower-pressure adsorption capacities of many more MOF, at 293-319 K, are tabulated. The various types of functionalities that have been explored to date for prepg. materials with enhanced CO2 capture performance are outlined, including amines, strongly polarizing org. functionalities, and exposed metal cation sites. The synthesis of continuous films of MOF and their use in membranes for gas sepn. are examd., with the tabulation of the CO2 sepn. performance of MOF mixed-matrix membranes. A final section outlines main issues that need to be addressed to achieve next-generation materials capable of fulfilling the criteria required for the gas sepns. relevant to post-combustion CO2 capture, pre-combustion CO2 capture, and oxy-fuel combustion.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhs12hsLzE&md5=eb8236e7dfe12981387c71415374f958

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Targeted Structure Modulation of "Pillar-Layered" Metal-Organic Frameworks for CO2 Capture
      Xuan, Zhi-Hong; Zhang, Da-Shuai; Chang, Ze; Hu, Tong-Liang; Bu, Xian-He
      Inorganic Chemistry (2014), 53 (17), 8985-8990CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Two new zinc MOFs with similar "pillar-layered" framework structures based on 1,1'-biphenyl-2,2',6,6'-tetracarboxylic acid (H4bpta) and two different bipyridine pillar ligands, namely {[Zn4(bpta)2(4-pna)2(H2O)2]·4DMF·3H2O}n (1) and {[Zn2(bpta)(bpy-ea)(H2O)]·2DMF·H2O}n (2) (4-pna = N-(4-pyridyl)isonicotinamide and bpy-ea = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane), were synthesized and studied with their CO2 adsorption properties. By anal. of the structure properties and the CO2 adsorption performances of these two MOFs, the introduction of polar acylamide groups via 4-pna resulted in 1 with enhanced CO2 capacity and CO2/CH4 selectivity at low pressure. In contrast, the framework of 2 shows flexible properties originating from the flexibility of the ethanediylidene group in the bpy-ea ligand, which benefits the sieve effect of pores to give higher CO2/CH4 selectivity at a relatively high pressure range.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Comprehensive study of carbon dioxide adsorption in the metal-organic frameworks M2(dobdc) (M = Mg, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn)
      Queen, Wendy L.; Hudson, Matthew R.; Bloch, Eric D.; Mason, Jarad A.; Gonzalez, Miguel I.; Lee, Jason S.; Gygi, David; Howe, Joshua D.; Lee, Kyuho; Darwish, Tamim A.; James, Michael; Peterson, Vanessa K.; Teat, Simon J.; Smit, Berend; Neaton, Jeffrey B.; Long, Jeffrey R.; Brown, Craig M.
      Chemical Science (2014), 5 (12), 4569-4581CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Anal. of the CO2 adsorption properties of a well-known series of metal-org. frameworks M2(dobdc) (dobdc4- = 2,5-dioxido-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate; M = Mg, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn) is carried out in tandem with in situ structural studies to identify the host-guest interactions that lead to significant differences in isosteric heats of CO2 adsorption. Neutron and X-ray powder diffraction and single crystal X-ray diffraction expts. are used to unveil the site-specific binding properties of CO2 within many of these materials while systematically varying both the amt. of CO2 and the temp. Unlike previous studies, we show that CO2 adsorbed at the metal cations exhibits intramol. angles with minimal deviations from 180°, a finding that indicates a strongly electrostatic and physisorptive interaction with the framework surface and sheds more light on the ongoing discussion regarding whether CO2 adsorbs in a linear or nonlinear geometry. This has important implications for proposals that have been made to utilize these materials for the activation and chem. conversion of CO2. For the weaker CO2 adsorbents, significant elongation of the metal-O(CO2) distances are obsd. and diffraction expts. addnl. reveal that secondary CO2 adsorption sites, while likely stabilized by the population of the primary adsorption sites, significantly contribute to adsorption behavior at ambient temp. D. functional theory calcns. including van der Waals dispersion quant. corroborate and rationalize observations regarding intramol. CO2 angles and trends in relative geometric properties and heats of adsorption in the M2(dobdc)-CO2 adducts.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsVCjtb%252FJ&md5=a3617bcec8b6bfa8605de53bd5959245

      Du, M.; Li, C. P.; Chen, M.; Ge, Z. W.; Wang, X.; Wang, L.; Liu, C. S. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2014, 136, 10906– 10909
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Divergent Kinetic and Thermodynamic Hydration of a Porous Cu(II) Coordination Polymer with Exclusive CO2 Sorption Selectivity
      Du, Miao; Li, Cheng-Peng; Chen, Min; Ge, Zhi-Wei; Wang, Xi; Wang, Lei; Liu, Chun-Sen
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136 (31), 10906-10909CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A MOF material, [Cu(tba)2]n (tba = 4-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)benzoate), which shows high CO2 adsorption selectivity over CH4-H2-O2-Ar-N2 gases (with IAST selectivity of 41-68 at 273 K and 33-51 at 293 K) is reported. By using a crit. point dryer, the CO2 mols. can be well sealed in the 1D channels of [Cu(tba)2]n to allow a single-crystal X-ray anal., which reveals the presence of not only Cδ+-H···Oδ- bonds between the host framework and CO2 but also quadrupole- quadrupole (CO2δ-···δ+CO2) interactions between the CO2 mols. Furthermore, [Cu(tba)2]n will suffer divergent kinetic and thermodn. hydration processes to form its isostructural hydrate {[Cu(tba)2](H2O)}n and a mononuclear complex [Cu(tba)2(H2O)4] via single-crystal to single-crystal transformations.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Zn(II)-Benzotriazolate Clusters Based Amide Functionalized Porous Coordination Polymers with High CO2 Adsorption Selectivity

      Inorganic Chemistry (2014), 53 (17), 8842-8844CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Two new porous coordination polymers (PCPs), [Zn5(L1)(btz)6(H2O)(NO3)]·5DMA·5H2O and [Zn9(L2)2(btz)12]·14H2O (btz = benzotriazolate), based on different nanosized C3 symmetry ligands I [X = 4-CO2H, (L1); X = 3-CO2H (L2)] and Zn(II)-benzotriazolate clusters were synthesized solvothermally. Both of the desolvated complexes show selective uptake of CO2 over CH4 and N2 at ambient temp.

      A flexible porous Cu(II) bis-imidazolate framework with ultrahigh concentration of active sites for efficient and recyclable CO2 capture
      Zhou, Dong-Dong; He, Chun-Ting; Liao, Pei-Qin; Xue, Wei; Zhang, Wei-Xiong; Zhou, Hao-Long; Zhang, Jie-Peng; Chen, Xiao-Ming
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2013), 49 (100), 11728-11730CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      By virtue of planar Cu2(μ-OH)22+ cluster units, a flexible porous metal azolate framework not only adsorbs large amts. of CO2 (19.6% or 266 g L-1 at 298 K and 1 atm) with a high zero-coverage adsorption enthalpy (-47 kJ mol-1), but also desorbs quickly at very low temps. The reaction between [Cu(NH3)2]OH (6) and H2bdim (5) at room temp. generates [Cu2(μ-OH)2(bdim)].5.4H2O (1), and the byproduct is [Cu2(μ-OCH3)2(bdim)].C6H6 (2). The bulk powder of 1 can be prepd. by heterogeneous reaction of H2bdim and Cu(OH)2 at room temp. for 5 days.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhvVWmt7zF&md5=8c9485cc3b506fd1d226e7f6dc73d1b1
    90. 90
      Planas, N.; Dzubak, A. L.; Poloni, R.; Lin, L.-C.; McManus, A.; McDonald, T. M.; Neaton, J. B.; Long, J. R.; Smit, B.; Gagliardi, L. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2013, 135, 7402– 7405
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      90
      The Mechanism of Carbon Dioxide Adsorption in an Alkylamine-Functionalized Metal-Organic Framework
      Planas, Nora; Dzubak, Allison L.; Poloni, Roberta; Lin, Li-Chiang; McManus, Alison; McDonald, Thomas M.; Neaton, Jeffrey B.; Long, Jeffrey R.; Smit, Berend; Gagliardi, Laura
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2013), 135 (20), 7402-7405CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The mechanism of CO2 adsorption in the amine-functionalized metal-org. framework mmen-Mg2(dobpdc) (dobpdc4- = 4,4'-dioxidobiphenyl-3,3'-dicarboxylate; mmen = N,N'-dimethylethylenediamine) was characterized by quantum-chem. calcns. The material was calcd. to demonstrate 2:2 amine:CO2 stoichiometry with a higher capacity and weaker CO2 binding energy than for the 2:1 stoichiometry obsd. in most amine-functionalized adsorbents. The authors explain this behavior in the form of a hydrogen-bonded complex involving two carbamic acid moieties resulting from the adsorption of CO2 onto the secondary amines.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXmt1yksL4%253D&md5=cad52dc6365aad293c373a798702a607
    91. 91
      Du, L.; Lu, Z.; Zheng, K.; Wang, J.; Zheng, X.; Pan, Y.; You, X.; Bai, J. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2013, 135, 562– 565
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      91
      Fine-Tuning Pore Size by Shifting Coordination Sites of Ligands and Surface Polarization of Metal-Organic Frameworks To Sharply Enhance the Selectivity for CO2
      Du, Liting; Lu, Zhiyong; Zheng, Kaiyuan; Wang, Junyi; Zheng, Xin; Pan, Yi; You, Xiaozeng; Bai, Junfeng
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2013), 135 (2), 562-565CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Based upon the (3,6)-connected metal-org. framework {Cu(L1)·2H2O·1.5DMF}∞ (L1 = 5-(pyridin-4-yl)isophthalic acid) (SYSU, for Sun Yat-Sen University), iso-reticular {Cu(L2)·DMF}∞ (L2 = 5-(pyridin-3-yl)isophthalic acid) (NJU-Bai7; NJU-Bai for Nanjing University Bai group) and {Cu(L3)·DMF·H2O}∞ (L3 = 5-(pyrimidin-5-yl)isophthalic acid) (NJU-Bai8) were designed by shifting the coordination sites of ligands to fine-tune pore size and polarizing the inner surface with uncoordinated N atoms, resp., with almost no changes in surface area or porosity. Compared with those of the prototype SYSU, both the adsorption enthalpy and selectivity of CO2 for NJU-Bai7 and NJU-Bai8 have been greatly enhanced, which makes NJU-Bai7 and NJU-Bai8 good candidates for postcombustion CO2 capture. Notably, the CO2 adsorption enthalpy of NJU-Bai7 is the highest reported so far among the MOFs without any polarizing functional groups or open metal sites. Meanwhile, NJU-Bai8 exhibits high uptake of CO2 and good CO2/CH4 selectivity at high pressure, which are quite valuable characteristics in the purifn. of natural gases.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhvV2gsLvN&md5=95669e5c19fa61e7227828db666e414a
    92. 92
      Huang, X. C.; Luo, W.; Shen, Y. F.; Lin, X. J.; Li, D. Chem. Commun. (Cambridge, U.K.) 2008, 3995– 3997
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      92
      A metal-organic framework containing discrete single-walled nanotubes based on curved trinuclear [Cu3(μ3-O)(μ-OH)(triazolate)2]+ building blocks
      Huang, Xiao-Chun; Luo, Wei; Shen, Yu-Feng; Lin, Xin-Jian; Li, Dan
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2008), (34), 3995-3997CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A metal-org. nanotubular architecture, {[Cu3(μ3-O)(μ-OH)(1,2,4-triazolate)2]3(μ3-Cl)(μ3-H2CA)}·8.5H2O (H3CA = cyanuric acid) was built from parallel-aligned single-walled nanotubes which interlink by μ3-bridged counterions, representing the first example of coordination nanotubes presumably generated from two-dimensional (2D) sheets.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtVKisrrK&md5=eade5d6117680000f042fbeaa6731e17
    93. 93
      Gargiulo, N.; Imperatore, M.; Aprea, P.; Caputo, D. Microporous Mesoporous Mater. 2011, 145, 74– 79
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      93
      Synthesis and characterization of a microporous copper triazolate as a water vapor adsorbent
      Gargiulo, Nicola; Imperatore, Maria; Aprea, Paolo; Caputo, Domenico
      Microporous and Mesoporous Materials (2011), 145 (1-3), 74-79CODEN: MIMMFJ; ISSN:1387-1811. (Elsevier Inc.)
      To better understand the water vapor adsorption behavior of metal org. frameworks, a microporous copper triazolate was synthesized and used as a substrate to evaluate water vapor adsorption isotherms at four different temps. (293, 303, 323 and 343 K). Samples of [Cu3(II)(triazolate)3(OH)3(H2O)4]·4.5H2O were obtained as powders by partially modifying a procedure reported in the literature and characterized by means of X-ray diffraction, SEM, particle size distribution, thermogravimetry and microporosimetric anal. The exptl. data for the water vapor adsorption were submitted to non-linear regression using the semiempirical Sips equation, which led to a good correlation between model curves and exptl. points. Moreover, the dependence of the isosteric heat on the fractional coverage of the adsorbent was successfully calcd. by the van't Hoff equation and Sips theor. isotherms.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhtValsbfJ&md5=5434635c1fbe71c587032a8bf754fa51

      ARTICLE SECTIONS

      This article references 93 other publications.

      1. 1
        Stock, N.; Biswas, S. Chem. Rev. 2012, 112, 933– 969
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1
        Synthesis of Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOFs): Routes to Various MOF Topologies, Morphologies, and Composites
        Stock, Norbert; Biswas, Shyam
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 933-969CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. The synthesis of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) has attracted immense attention during the last 2 decades due to the possibility to obtain a large variety of aesthetically interesting structures that could also be of great interest for applications in a no. of fields related to porous materials. This includes the more traditional areas of storage, sepn., and catalysis, which are based on the pore size and shape as well as the host guest interactions involved. In addn., biomedical applications or the use as sensor materials are currently intensively investigated. Although MOF synthesis was originally set out for making new compds. and structures with interesting properties, the field has matured and is broadening its scope. This holds for the synthesis methods applied as well as the areas of application. While conventional syntheses methods have been widely used, the fields of mechano-, sono-, and electrochem. synthesis as well as microwave-assisted syntheses are just emerging. They have demonstrated to be applicable for some compds., often under milder reaction conditions, yielding materials with different particle sizes and properties. This could be of interest for up-scaling of syntheses and the application of MOFs.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhsV2ju73P&md5=76323bab0fb9da58bcdf45e03537eed7

        O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Chem. Rev. 2012, 112, 675– 702
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2
        Deconstructing the Crystal Structures of Metal-Organic Frameworks and Related Materials into Their Underlying Nets
        O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 675-702CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Redn. of complex crystal structures of metal-org. frameworks and related materials to an underlying topol. is discussed. An approach to identify vertices of underlying nets is presented.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhtFOmtr7L&md5=201baa336aa2d3edcb2099a649e840fe

        Li, J. R.; Sculley, J.; Zhou, H. C. Chem. Rev. 2012, 112, 869– 932
